Descriptions: Calculate the solubility of $\ce{BaSO_{4}}$ at 298 K in g per 100 g of water given that $K_{\text{sp}} = 1.07\times 10^{-10}$.
Reference: Inorganic Chemistry _ Edition 4 -- Prof Catherine Housecroft, Alan G_ Sharpe -- 4th ed_, Harlow, England, New York, England, 2012 -- Pearson Education, 7.13

Descriptions: How many radial nodes does each of the following orbitals possess: (a) $2s$; (b) $4s$; (c) $3p$; (d) $5d$; (e) $1s$; (f) $4p$?
Reference: Inorganic Chemistry _ Edition 4 -- Prof Catherine Housecroft, Alan G_ Sharpe -- 4th ed_, Harlow, England, New York, England, 2012 -- Pearson Education, 1.13

Descriptions: Dissolve 26.3 g of (CdSO_4) solid in 1000 g of water. Its freezing point is 0.285 K lower than that of pure water. Given that (k_f) of water is (1.86\ K，kg，mol^{-1}), calculate the degree of dissociation of (CdSO_4) in the solution and present the answer as a percentage.

When oleic acid glyceride is metabolized in the human body, the following reaction occurs:   $$\ce{C_{57}H_{104}O_{6}(s) + 80O_{2}(g) = 57CO_{2}(g) + 52H_{2}O(l)}$$   $\Delta_{r}H_{m}^{\ominus} = -3.35\times10^{4}\ \text{kJ，mol}^{-1}$. Calculate the reaction progress when 1 kg of this fat is consumed, and how much heat will be released.

Try to calculate the \(\Delta_{r}H_{m}^{\ominus}\) of the reaction \(\ce{CO(g) + 2H_{2}(g)\xlongequal{岸晒質} CH_{3}OH(l)}\) based on the thermodynamic data of the known reactions:    \(\ce{2C(graphite) + O_{2}(g) = 2CO(g)}\) \(\Delta_{r}H_{m}^{\ominus}(1) = -221.0\ \text{kJ，mol}^{-1}\)    \(\ce{C(graphite) + O_{2}(g) = CO_{2}(g)}\) \(\Delta_{r}H_{m}^{\ominus}(2) = -393.5\ \text{kJ，mol}^{-1}\)    \(\ce{2CH_{3}OH(l) + 3O_{2}(g) = 2CO_{2}(g) + 4H_{2}O(l)}\) \(\Delta_{r}H_{m}^{\ominus}(3) = -1452.2\ \text{kJ，mol}^{-1}\)   ∠ \(\ce{2H_{2}(g) + O_{2}(g) = 2H_{2}O(l)}\) \(\Delta_{r}H_{m}^{\ominus}(4) = -571.6\ \text{kJ，mol}^{-1}\)
The half - life of a first - order reaction at 400 K is 100 times that at 500 K. Try to estimate the activation energy of this reaction.

At a certain temperature, for the reaction:   $$\ce{H_{2}(g) + Br_{2}(g)\rightleftharpoons 2HBr(g)}$$   \(K_{c}=8.10\times10^{3}\). Calculate the equilibrium conversion of \(\ce{Br_{2}}\) in two cases:   1. The initial concentrations of \(\ce{H_{2}(g)}\) and \(\ce{Br_{2}(g)}\) are both \(1.00\ \text{mol，dm}^{-3}\).   2. The initial concentrations of \(\ce{H_{2}(g)}\) and \(\ce{Br_{2}(g)}\) are \(10.00\ \text{mol，dm}^{-3}\) and \(1.00\ \text{mol，dm}^{-3}\) respectively.

A certain amount of ammonium chloride decomposes upon heating according to the following equation:   $$\ce{NH_{4}Cl(s)\rightleftharpoons NH_{3}(g) + HCl(g)}$$   It is known that for the reaction, \(\Delta_{r}H_{m}^{\ominus}=161\ \text{kJ，mol}^{-1}\) and \(\Delta_{r}S_{m}^{\ominus}=250\ \text{J，mol}^{-1}，\text{K}^{-1}\). Try to calculate the total pressure (kPa) of the system when equilibrium is reached at 700 K.

For the reaction:   $$\ce{2NaHCO_{3}(s)\rightleftharpoons Na_{2}CO_{3}(s) + CO_{2}(g) + H_{2}O(g)}$$   The standard molar reaction enthalpy is \(1.29\times10^{2}\ \text{kJ，mol}^{-1}\). If \(K^{\ominus}=1.66\times10^{-5}\) at 303 K, try to calculate \(K^{\ominus}\) at 393 K.
LiBr has a NaCl - type crystal structure and a density of (3.464\ \text{g，cm}^{-3}). Calculate the distance (pm) between (\text{Li}^+) and (\text{Br}^-).

The solubility of \(\ce{Mg(OH)_{2}}\) in water is \(1.12\times10^{-4}\ \text{mol，dm}^{-3}\). Try to calculate its solubility - product constant \(K_{sp}^{\ominus}\). If \(0.10\ \text{dm}^3\) of \(0.10\ \text{mol，dm}^{-3}\) \(\ce{MgCl_{2}}\) solution is mixed with \(0.10\ \text{dm}^3\) of \(0.10\ \text{mol，dm}^{-3}\) \(\ce{NH_{3}，H_{2}O}\) solution, try to find out how many grams of \(\ce{NH_{4}Cl}\) solid need to be added to inhibit the precipitation of \(\ce{Mg(OH)_{2}}\).   It is known that the \(K_{b}^{\ominus}\) of \(\ce{NH_{3}，H_{2}O}\) is \(1.8\times10^{-5}\).

It is known that for the electrode reaction \(\ce{Cu^{+} + e^{-}=Cu}\), \(E^{\ominus} = 0.52\ \text{V}\), and the solubility - product constant \(K_{sp}\) of \(\ce{CuCl}\) is \(1.7\times10^{-7}\). Try to calculate the standard electrode potential \(E^{\ominus}\) for the electrode reaction \(\ce{CuCl + e^{-}=Cu + Cl^{-}}\).

It is known that at 298 K, the standard molar Gibbs free energy of formation \(\Delta_{f}G_{m}^{\ominus}\) of \(\ce{Ca(OH)_{2}(s)}\) is \(- 897.5\ \text{kJ，mol}^{-1}\), and that of \(\ce{H_{2}O(l)}\) is \(-237.1\ \text{kJ，mol}^{-1}\). The ion - product constant of water \(K_{w}^{\ominus}=1.00\times10^{-14}\). Try to calculate the electrode potential of the electrode \(\ce{Ca(OH)_{2}/Ca}\).

It is known that for the acid - dissociation equilibrium constants of \(H_2S\) aqueous solution, \(K_1 = 1.1\times10^{-7}\) and \(K_2 = 1.3\times10^{-13}\), and the solubility - product constant \(K_{sp}^{\ominus}\) of \(CuS\) is \(6.3\times10^{-36}\).   The electrode reactions and their standard electrode potentials are:   - \(\ce{NO^{-}_{3} + 4H^{+} + 3e^{-}=NO + 2H_{2}O}\) \(E^{\ominus}=0.96\ \text{V}\)   - \(\ce{S + 2H^{+} + 2e^{-}=H_{2}S}\) \(E^{\ominus}=0.14\ \text{V}\)   Try to calculate the equilibrium constant \(K^{\ominus}\) for the reaction \(\ce{3CuS + 2NO^{-}_{3} + 8H^{+}=3Cu^{2 + } + 2NO + 3S + 4H_{2}O}\).

It is known that:   - For the electrode reaction \(\ce{Cu^{2+} + 2e^{-}=Cu}\), \(E^{\ominus}=0.34\ \text{V}\)   - For the electrode reaction \(\ce{Cu^{+} + e^{-}=Cu}\), \(E^{\ominus}=0.52\ \text{V}\)   - For the electrode reaction \(\ce{Cu^{2+} + Br^{-} + e^{-}=CuBr}\), \(E^{\ominus}=0.65\ \text{V}\)   Try to calculate the solubility - product constant \(K_{sp}^{\ominus}\) of \(\ce{CuBr}\).

In a solution, the initial concentrations of \(\ce{Cu^{2+}}\) and \(\ce{NH_{3}，H_{2}O}\) are \(0.20\ \text{mol，dm}^{-3}\) and \(1.0\ \text{mol，dm}^{-3}\) respectively. It is known that the stability constant \(K_{stable}^{\ominus}\) of \(\ce{[Cu(NH_{3})_{4}]^{2+}}\) is \(2.1\times10^{13}\). Try to calculate the residual concentration of \(\ce{Cu^{2+}}\) in the solution at equilibrium.

It is known that the standard molar entropies \(S_{m}^{\ominus}\) of solid iodine \(\ce{I_{2}(s)}\) and iodine vapor \(\ce{I_{2}(g)}\) are \(116.1\ \text{J，mol}^{-1}，\text{K}^{-1}\) and \(260.7\ \text{J，mol}^{-1}，\text{K}^{-1}\) respectively, and the standard molar enthalpy of formation \(\Delta_{f}H_{m}^{\ominus}\) of iodine vapor is \(62.4\ \text{kJ，mol}^{-1}\). Try to calculate the normal sublimation temperature of solid iodine.

The concentration of the solution of the sodium salt (NaX) of a monoprotic weak acid is \(0.2\ \text{mol，dm}^{-3}\). Given that its pH is 9, try to calculate the dissociation equilibrium constant \(K_{a}^{\ominus}\) of this weak acid HX.

A strong base is used to titrate a monoprotic weak acid. When \(3.50\ \text{cm}^3\) of the strong base solution is added, the pH of the system is 4.15. When \(5.70\ \text{cm}^3\) of the strong base solution is added, the pH of the system is 4.44. Try to calculate the dissociation equilibrium constant of this weak acid.

At \(1.013〜10^{5}\ \text{Pa}\) and \(373\ \text{K}\), \(18\ \text{g}\) of \(\ce{H_{2}O(l)}\) vaporizes into \(\ce{H_{2}O(g)}\), absorbing \(40.58\ \text{kJ}\) of heat. Try to calculate \(\Delta U\) for this process.

At \(1.013〜10^{5}\ \text{Pa}\) and \(373\ \text{K}\), \(18\ \text{g}\) of \(\ce{H_{2}O(l)}\) vaporizes into \(\ce{H_{2}O(g)}\), absorbing \(40.58\ \text{kJ}\) of heat. Try to calculate \(\Delta S\) for this process.

(\ce{SO_{2}Cl_{2}(g) = SO_{2}(g) + Cl_{2}(g)}\) is a first - order reaction. The rate constant \(k\) at a certain temperature is \(3.8〜10^{-5}\ \text{s}^{-1}\). After heating at this temperature for \(1.5\ \text{h}\), what is the degree of dissociation of \(\ce{SO_{2}Cl_{2}}\)?
